description: Dive into "Whispers of Love in Kanazawa" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Whispers of Love in Kanazawa

places.generalDescription: Higashi Chaya District, also known as The Eastern Teahouse District, is a well-preserved traditional neighborhood in Kanazawa. It features beautifully maintained teahouses and geisha houses that were once frequented by feudal lords and high-ranking officials during the Edo period. Some of these historic buildings have been transformed into restaurants and shops selling local goods, while others remain intact as teahouses for visitors to enjoy.

sources.snippet: Higashi Chaya is the largest of the three, where still-functioning geisha teahouses stand side-by-side with historical buildings now functioning as restaurants, shops, and cafes. Geisha teahouses are mainly exclusive and by invitation only, but one of the teahouses hosts special events where visitors can attend casual performances explained in English. Even if you can't attend an event, pay attention as you walk through the streets, and you might overhear a geisha song accompanied by the traditional shamisen stringed instrument floating down from an upper floor.
sources.siteName: VISIT KANAZAWA, JAPAN - Official Travel Guide
sources.shortName: Night Time Activity in Kanazawa

sources.snippet: Built in 1820, Kaikaro is the biggest chaya (teahouse) in the center of the main street of Higashi Chaya District. Marvel at the exquisite interior with its wooden sliding doors, vermilion-lacquered stairs, bold paintings, and a tea room with gold-woven tatami mats. Kaikaro offers feasts and entertainment following the traditional, referral-based admittance policy in the evenings, but are open to the public during the day.
sources.shortName: Things To Do | Kanazawa Port

sources.snippet:
Higashi-Chaya-gai Geisha District in Kanazawa
An easy walk east of Omicho Market or Kanazawa Castle Park, the Higashi Chaya Area is a lovely neighborhood of beautifully preserved geisha houses. Many have now been converted into restaurants or teahouses. This area can get very crowded with tourists, but you can escape the masses by heading away from the main street of the area.
sources.shortName: Things To Do In Kanazawa

sources.snippet: The Higashi Chaya District is known for its wooden teahouses or chaya, which have been standing since Japan‚Äôs Edo period. For a traditional experience, visit Ochaya Shima (ÂøóÊë©), a preserved geisha house from the 19th century. Selected as a National Cultural Asset, Shima offers a look into the lifestyles and entertainment of times gone by.
sources.shortName: 30 of the Best Things to Do in Kanazawa | Japan Travel by NAVITIME

sources.snippet: Now it‚Äôs time to walk around one of the most beautiful districts of Kanazawa!. The Higashi Chaya District is the largest teahouse and Geisha district in Kanazawa. Dating back to the Edo period, this district keeps it‚Äôs original look with traditional architecture, original Chayas (teahouses) that are hundreds of years old, and so forth.
sources.shortName: How to Spend the Best 2 Days in Kanazawa

sources.snippet: The old tea district area of Kanazawa is lined with traditional buildings, many of them housing tea houses where you can sample tea and a selection of wagashi, Japanese confectionery. There's also many people who rent a kimono here, which you can wear for a day to take pictures in!
sources.shortName: Kanazawa ‚Äî Natalie Choi Events

sources.snippet: Step back in time in the Higashi-Chaya District, one of Kanazawa's largest geisha districts. Wander the narrow, winding streets lined with beautifully preserved wooden teahouses, known as chaya, where geishas have entertained since the Edo Period (1603‚Äì1868).
sources.shortName: 10 Things To Do in Kanazawa: Top Must-See Attractions

sources.snippet: Did you know Kanazawa has a Geisha district similar to Kyoto‚Äôs Gion?. Girls in yukata getting in the way of Higashi Chaya. It‚Äôs called Higashi Chaya, and it‚Äôs a relic of Kanazawa‚Äôs very own Hanamachi (geisha district).
sources.siteName: I'm Still Hungry | A Food & Travel Blog
sources.shortName: Still Hungry in Kanazawa | Ishikawa, Japan

sources.snippet: Explore the historic Higashi Chaya District, known for its well-preserved geisha houses and teahouses, and immerse in Kanazawa‚Äôs traditional architecture.
sources.shortName: Romantic Tour In Kanazawa
30 Things to Do Around Kanazawa & Where to Stay

places.name: Higashi Chaya District

reviews.text: This is an old Samurai district in Kanazawa! The structures are idyllic of the time period and are best when visited when no one is on the streets (best pictures!). Not much was open when we were walking around during sunset, but that doesn't mean there aren't places to eat. Truly a cool place to visit!

The district is full of old tradition tea houses and is well known for its gold leaf ice cream. It was lovely to spend a couple hours walking around exploring the local stores. There is a tourist information centre which provides free information, bathrooms, water and a place to rest. It gets pretty busy (went in January) but it's still enjoyable.

Historic tea house district with charming old streets and well-preserved buildings. Many tea houses here offer dessert and the popular gold leaf ice cream.

The area is quite big and the streets are photogenic, perfect for a slow stroll. I visited on a Wednesday, and I am not sure if it is a bad day to visit Kanazawa, but some of the shops were not open. I should have spent more time here and explored the area across the river too. Feels like there is more to see if you take your time.

places.generalDescription: Kenroku-en is one of Japan's most celebrated landscaped gardens, known as one of the country's 'Three Famous Gardens.' The name refers to the six classical elements of an ideal garden, and it offers a seamless transition through sculpted pine trees, stone lanterns, and ponds. Originally part of a castle's grounds, this garden has developed over several hundred years and is designed to be beautiful in every season.

sources.shortName: Must-see attractions Kanazawa, Kanazawa & the Hokuriku Coast

sources.snippet: A private tour led by a knowledgeable local guide promises to immerse visitors in the city‚Äôs enchanting sights, from the meticulously designed Kenroku-en Garden to the well-preserved historic districts. Guests will have the opportunity to explore the intricate craftsmanship of gold leaf artistry and lacquerware, while indulging in the culinary delights that have made Kanazawa renowned. This immersive experience promises to capture the essence of the city‚Äôs timeless charm, leaving travelers with a deeper appreciation for Kanazawa‚Äôs unique blend of tradition and modernity.
sources.shortName: Romantic Tour In Kanazawa

sources.snippet: The castle also sits literally across the stress from Kenroku-en, the Kanazawa garden that‚Äôs become one of my favorite in Japan over the years. Local people say this is a place you need to see in all four seasons, and I‚Äôm happy to have experienced what seems to be the rarest (winter) during my most recent trip. My favorite part about this most beautiful of Kanazawa things to do is how diverse it is horticulturally, from the twisty pines that line the shores of Kasumigaike Pond, to a lush  ume plum grove that boasts bursts of bright pink in winter.
sources.shortName: The Ultimate Kanazawa Travel Guide

sources.snippet: Designated as one of The Three Great Gardens of Japan, Kenroku-en (ÂÖºÂÖ≠Âúí) offers breathtaking sights in every season. With tranquil ponds, arching bridges and carefully tended greenery, this garden deserves to be explored slowly. Watching the morning sunlight illuminate the garden is highly recommended and relaxing in one of the garden‚Äôs teahouses before setting off again for a stroll is sure to reenergize you after a busy trip.
sources.shortName: 30 of the Best Things to Do in Kanazawa | Japan Travel by NAVITIME

sources.snippet: Kanazawa is built around a green hilltop district that is composed of Kanazawa Castle Park and Kenroku-en Garden, two of the city‚Äôs main sights. This green core is about 10 minutes‚Äô walk southwest from Omicho Market. Tucked along the southwest side of Kenroku-en, you‚Äôll find the city‚Äôs museum district, which is home to the Kanazawa Prefectural Museum of Art and the 21st Century Museum of Contemporary Art.
sources.shortName: Kanazawa Districts

sources.snippet: Now that you‚Äôve visited the Maeda Clan‚Äôs residency, its time to visit their most beautiful creation and Japan‚Äôs most beautiful garden ‚Äì the Kenrokuen. As its name states, the Kenrokuen is a ‚Äúgarden of the six sublimities‚Äù ‚Äì the six features that make a garden perfect. The six sublimities consist of artifice, water, views, seclusion, antiquity, and spaciousness.
sources.shortName: How to Spend the Best 2 Days in Kanazawa

sources.snippet: After smashing four cakes, you‚Äôd forgive me for wanting to take a bit of a walk to stave off the inevitable sugar rush (and shortly after that, the coma). There are few strolling areas more appropriate for a tourist than Kanazawa Castle. Many major cities in Japan sport a flagship castle compound and Kanazawa Castle is this city‚Äôs eponymous example.
sources.siteName: I'm Still Hungry | A Food & Travel Blog
sources.shortName: Still Hungry in Kanazawa | Ishikawa, Japan

sources.snippet: Kenroku-en was dead quiet, save for the oldest fountain in Japan bubbling nearby. To enter, you need to pay a small fee. We saw several snowmen built by locals, and the paths winding through the park lead us through tall pine trees that shielded us from the falling snow.
sources.shortName: Reddit - Dive into anything

sources.snippet: Enjoy a host of affordable traditional attractions, such as strolling through the beautiful Kenroku-en garden or exploring the samurai district of Nagamachi. Try local foods at a reasonable price, including the famous sushi, bento boxes and traditional wagashi sweets.
sources.shortName: Tripper - Guide - A romantic day trip to Kanazawa, Japan

sources.snippet: One of the Three Great Gardens of Japan, Kenroku-en is an expansive garden set in the heart of Kanazawa and located conveniently across the street from Kanazawa Castle. It's a very clean and well-maintained park, and beautiful all seasons of the year.
sources.shortName: Kanazawa ‚Äî Natalie Choi Events

places.name: Kenroku-en

reviews.text: One of the most beautiful gardens I've had the pleasure to visit. Different ponds are connected with singing streams, with two large tea houses overlooking the largest pond. Trees are spectu, some of them three and two centuries old. Even with the summer heat, it's an incredible place to wander and wonder about.

We went here during the summer. The park was a welcoming place to cool down.
It's so beautiful! Go visit the house of the Maeda wife's. It's amazing.
We also found a beautiful restaurant at a waterfall with the most delicious food.

Definitely a highlight in Kanazawa. Went there at 4pm and the sun was on its way down so it was so nice. Wasn't that just. It's only 320yen to get in and closes at 6pm. Pretty chilled walk and feel like I could do it again as i definitely probably missed some elements. Might also be nice doing the walk without taking any pictures.

places.generalDescription: Omicho Market, known as the "kitchen of Kanazawa," is a bustling indoor complex with over 170 stalls offering an array of fresh produce, seafood, and meat. The market is particularly famous for its variety of fresh seafood caught in the nearby Sea of Japan, including yellowtail, shrimp available year-round, and crab starting from November. Visitors can also explore shops selling local fruits and vegetables not commonly found elsewhere.

sources.snippet: As I mentioned earlier, it was rainy and miserable when I first arrived to Kanazawa for my second trip‚ÄîI spent hours in the Kanazawa market not so much because I wanted to, but because I didn‚Äôt have a choice. The seafood at Omicho Market is varied (and very beautiful), and lives up to the hype around it in as much as that. I will say that it‚Äôs a bit pricey for my taste, which instead pushed me to try (for the first time ever!) gold-leaf soft cream.
sources.shortName: The Ultimate Kanazawa Travel Guide

sources.snippet: Start your day off at the Omicho Market, a 300 year old food market and Kanazawa‚Äôs largest market since it‚Äôs establishment in 1721. Omicho Market has over 180 stalls that range from fresh seafood to street food, traditional Japanese sweets, home goods, and more. By going to this market, you will immerse yourself in the daily life of the locals, experience the market culture, and try delicious foods.
sources.shortName: How to Spend the Best 2 Days in Kanazawa

sources.snippet: For a sensory feast, wander through Omicho Market, Kanazawa's bustling food hub that has been operating for over 300 years. This sprawling market features more than 170 stores, including numerous fishmongers selling freshly caught seafood from the Sea of Japan. You'll also find unique local fruits and vegetables, marine products, clothing and several restaurants.
sources.shortName: 10 Things To Do in Kanazawa: Top Must-See Attractions

sources.snippet: ≈åmich≈ç Market, also known as Kanazawa‚Äôs pantry, has around 170 shops on two sides of a narrow street. While it can be hard to find a vegetarian menu in one of the restaurants, it is a great place to source some fresh vegetables, fruits, and local specialties. Many shops also offer tasting samples, which is the best way to figure out the best snack as a souvenir.
sources.siteName: Vegetarian's Japan Guide | Ultimate Japan Guide, Vegetarian-Friendly, Hidden Gems in Japan
sources.shortName: Your Ultimate Kanazawa City Travel Guide 2024

sources.snippet: During your visit, shop for keepsakes to take home with you, like colorful Kutani ware porcelain, delicate lacquerware (urushi), and dazzling gilded crafts. Don't miss Ishikawa's famous foods, from seafood and sake to traditional sweets and snacks. Visit the Wajima Morning Market for fresh snacks and local crafts, and the Omicho Market for succulent seafood.
sources.shortName: Things To Do | Ishikawa Travel

sources.snippet: While not exclusively selling seafood, Omicho Fish Market is without doubt most famous for the delicious array of fresh seafood on sale at its 200 shops and stalls. The market is undercover and sells seafood from the fishing grounds in the nearby Sea of Japan. If you are a fan of seafood and in Kanazawa, you nearly have to go.
sources.shortName: 30 Things to Do Around Kanazawa & Where to Stay

sources.snippet: Affectionately known as Kanazawa‚Äôs Kitchen, the Omicho Market is packed with tasty sushi bars. You can take your time deciding as you wander through the covered market. But if you get there early, you might beat the crowds to a delicious kaisen-don or a bowl of sashimi over sushi rice.
sources.shortName: 30 of the Best Things to Do in Kanazawa | Japan Travel by NAVITIME

sources.snippet: A 15-minute walk southwest of the station brings you to Omicho Market, a fantastic food market that is like a mini Tsukiji. It‚Äôs a great place to explore on your way to Kanazawa Castle or Kenroku-en Garden (see following). There are plenty of restaurants in and around the market.
sources.shortName: Kanazawa Districts

sources.snippet: Could a town be considered a city without a flagship market?. At Kanazawa, Omicho Market is the one you‚Äôre looking for (and is only a 15 minute stroll from the station). For a city of only half a million, it‚Äôs surprisingly big, with over 200 stalls.
sources.siteName: I'm Still Hungry | A Food & Travel Blog
sources.shortName: Still Hungry in Kanazawa | Ishikawa, Japan

sources.snippet: The areas around Omicho Market, Korinbo and Katamachi are each illuminated with thousands of LED lights after dark, perfect for a romantic stroll. It somehow becomes even more romantic when the soft snowflakes begin to fall if that is even possible!
sources.siteName: VISIT KANAZAWA, JAPAN - Official Travel Guide
sources.shortName: Winter Attractions in Kanazawa | VISIT KANAZAWA

sources.snippet: Foodies should make a beeline for Omicho Market, where the city‚Äôs freshest seafood can be found. The market‚Äôs restaurants are superb; as are the eateries at the best places to stay in Kanazawa.
sources.shortName: Best places to stay in Kanazawa, Japan

sources.snippet: From fresh seafood straight from Japan Sea to vibrant fruits and steaming bowls of ramen and exotic fruits ‚Äì ≈åmich≈ç Market has something for everyone and is a must-do in Kanazawa!
sources.shortName: 11 Best things to do in Kanazawa, Japan: a curated travel guide

places.name: Omicho Market

reviews.text:
Lots of stalls selling a good variety of fresh seafood. In the morning, some of the market stalls offer a standing counter to purchase and eat on the spot. The majority of them are open for lunch, with some of them providing seating areas. In the evening, only a few restaurants are open for dinner and they close quite early at around 7-8pm.
There is a good variety of fresh seafood ranging from oysters to snow crabs, uni, sashimi and abalone. On average a bit pricey but worth it for the quality and freshness.
Highly recommend checking out the restaurants at the first floor only. We tried the restaurants on level 2 but they are way more expensive and simply do not provide the variety of seafood that the restaurants on level 1 offer.

One of my favorite fish markets across Japan, it is not overly crowded, seafood is fresh and more reasonably priced and the people are generally friendly. During crab season, definitely try it because it's just so good. The small stores at the back alleys have great seafood bowl options for lunch as well, explore around to find one that you like.

Loved loved loved. Pure joy when you find places like these when travelling, and no better way than to spend than with your sibs. Being able to taste local food and snacks.
We bought some bento eel rice sets for our lunch which was really yummy and tried the famous gold leaf ice cream! üç¶ üç±
Happy happy joy joy

places.generalDescription: Kanazawa Station is a popular landmark known for its striking architecture and convenient layout. The station features the impressive Tsuzumi-mon Gate, inspired by the traditional Noh drum, which welcomes travelers with its remarkable design. Additionally, the huge glass Motenashi Dome provides shelter from the elements and adds to the station's allure. Surrounding the station are numerous shopping and dining options, including Kanazawa Forus with seven floors of shops and restaurants.

sources.snippet: The parade starts at the east exit of Kanazawa Station, with spirited taiko drum performances in front of the iconic Tsuzumi-mon Gate, followed by an exuberant show of dancers, musicians, and performers dressed in 16-century costumes as samurai, feudal lords, and princesses. One of the most acrobatic performances you‚Äôll see is from firefighters teetering at the top of ladders as they perform a series of gymnastic stunts, much to the delight of festival onlookers. You‚Äôll get to watch the lion dance and historical re-enactments of Maeda Toshiie riding on horseback for an entertaining glimpse into Kanazawa history from Kanazawa Castle Park and in the street during the parade.
sources.siteName: VISIT KANAZAWA, JAPAN - Official Travel Guide
sources.shortName: Summer attraction in KanazawaÔΩúTrip IdeasÔΩúVISIT KANAZAWA, JAPAN

sources.snippet: While most major sights in the city are technically within walking distance, it‚Äôs not exactly time-efficient or easy on the feet to spend half an hour huffing it to another location. And while your first thought may be to take the train, Kanazawa isn‚Äôt very well connected within the city limits. That‚Äôs where buses come in.
sources.shortName: 30 of the Best Things to Do in Kanazawa | Japan Travel by NAVITIME

sources.snippet: You‚Äôll find plenty of shops and restaurants in the station building, as well as the main tourist information center. Right outside the station (on both sides), you‚Äôll find the city‚Äôs biggest hotels. You‚Äôll also find the Kanazawa Forus Building, which has a great collection of restaurants on the 6th floor.
sources.shortName: Kanazawa Districts

sources.snippet: The gardens are located just a short distance from Kanazawa Station, the city‚Äôs main transportation hub. Travelers can take bus lines that run directly to the gardens or opt for a leisurely stroll through the charming streets, passing by historic samurai districts and traditional tea houses along the way.
sources.shortName: Romantic Tour In Kanazawa
30 Things to Do Around Kanazawa & Where to Stay

places.name: Kanazawa Station

reviews.text: This is a lovely and culturally vibrant town - many tourist areas. The fish market is interesting and has lots of sushi options. Get the grilled mackerel sushi roll if you can. The castle gardens are beautiful.

Lovely town which looks like it has newly built infrastructure. Arty and foodie heaven.  Easy to navigate.
Only frustrating thing is local bus timetable/routes behind a paywall. Using Google is a bit limiting to plan trips somewhat.
We stayed in Nomachi tea district and walked mostly. We mainly walked back streets and ‚Äòdiscovered' many hole-in-the-wall eateries and bars.
Visit here soon as it is still not on the tourist radar.

April 13th, 2023:

What a beautiful station. Really cool design and architecture. The Kanazawa fountain sign is pretty cool too. Very creative

5 stars immediately.

places.generalDescription: Nestled near the picturesque Kenrokuen Garden, Kanazawa Castle is a captivating historical site that dates back to the 1580s. Although it lacks a castle tower, visitors can explore its well-preserved walls and gates, offering a glimpse into Japan's rich heritage. The surrounding park provides an immersive experience of ancient life. Restoration work on Ninomaru Palace is underway, promising an enhanced visit in the future.

sources.snippet: The parade starts at the east exit of Kanazawa Station, with spirited taiko drum performances in front of the iconic Tsuzumi-mon Gate, followed by an exuberant show of dancers, musicians, and performers dressed in 16-century costumes as samurai, feudal lords, and princesses. One of the most acrobatic performances you‚Äôll see is from firefighters teetering at the top of ladders as they perform a series of gymnastic stunts, much to the delight of festival onlookers. You‚Äôll get to watch the lion dance and historical re-enactments of Maeda Toshiie riding on horseback for an entertaining glimpse into Kanazawa history from Kanazawa Castle Park and in the street during the parade.
sources.siteName: VISIT KANAZAWA, JAPAN - Official Travel Guide
sources.shortName: Summer attraction in KanazawaÔΩúTrip IdeasÔΩúVISIT KANAZAWA, JAPAN

sources.snippet: Built in 1580 under orders from Oda Nobunaga, Kanazawa Castle was home to 14 generations of the powerful Maeda Clan*3 until 1869. Despite the numerous devastating fires (the most recent in 1881) that drastically changed the structure of the castle through the expansion of enclosure, building of canals and moats, moving of mansions of vassals among others, several buildings have been faithfully reconstructed based on their design in the 1850s. Discover why Kanazawa Castle has the most variety of stone walls among all the castles in Japan as you walk through its grounds.
sources.shortName: Things To Do | Kanazawa Port

sources.snippet: Kanazawa Castle is not, on its face, one of the most impressive in Japan, having been mostly re-constructed, and lacking a keep since its original one was destroyed in a 1602 fire. On the other hand, Kanazawa Castle Park is very beautiful (especially in the snow), and the museum inside the restored building is informative and interesting. It also happens to sit right in the middle of town (and all the other things to do in Kanazawa), which makes it a perfect place to begin exploring on your Kanazawa trip.
sources.shortName: The Ultimate Kanazawa Travel Guide

sources.snippet: Sitting pretty next to Kenrokuen Garden is the spectacular Kanazawa Castle. Built in the 1580s, after the defeat of the Peasant‚Äôs Kingdom, Japan‚Äôs only Buddhist kingdom, Kanazawa Castle and its park bring to life the city‚Äôs rich heritage. The turrets and the storehouse are open from 9 am until 4.30 pm, and strolling the grounds take you back to what life may have been like centuries before.
sources.shortName: A visitor‚Äôs guide to Kanazawa, Japan

sources.snippet: Ishikawa is an epicenter of traditional and contemporary Japanese art, design, culture, and craft. From the modern architecture of Kanazawa Station to the progressive 21st Century Museum of Contemporary Art, the traditional geisha performances at Yamanaka-za Theater to exquisite porcelain displays at the Kutani-yaki Art Museum, there is something to satisfy everyone's curiosity.
sources.shortName: Things To Do | Ishikawa Travel

sources.snippet: Kanazawa offers a unique blend of traditional Japan and modernity, making it an ideal destination for a romantic getaway. The city is home to beautifully landscaped gardens, historic temples, and the famous Kenrokuen Garden. Couples can also indulge in local delicacies such as sushi, seafood, and traditional Japanese sweets while exploring the charming streets of Kanazawa.
sources.shortName: Tripper - Guide - A romantic day trip to Kanazawa, Japan

sources.snippet: Kanazawa Castle and its garden, Kenrokuen, are prime spots that are must-visits for any tourists in Kanazawa. Kenrokuen, the top garden in the Three Great Gardens in Japan that took 180 years to complete, contains all six elements that make a great landscape. This is literally a place where you can hardly find a moment that one won‚Äôt find charming.
sources.siteName: Vegetarian's Japan Guide | Ultimate Japan Guide, Vegetarian-Friendly, Hidden Gems in Japan
sources.shortName: Your Ultimate Kanazawa City Travel Guide 2024

sources.snippet: Outside of the garden's Katsurazaka gate, the pedestrian road is lined with small restaurants and cafes serving casual lunch dishes, tea, and ice cream covered in gold leaf. Kanazawa accounts for 99% percent of all domestic gold leaf production. Several cafes, shops, and even museums offer gold leaf in various forms.
sources.shortName: Kenrokuen Garden | Travel Japan

sources.snippet: Explore the historic Higashi Chaya District, known for its well-preserved geisha houses and teahouses, and immerse in Kanazawa‚Äôs traditional architecture.
sources.shortName: Romantic Tour In Kanazawa

sources.snippet: Standing proudly amidst an extensive park, the castle is a testament to Kanazawa‚Äôs rich heritage. Make sure to stroll in the extensive gardens!
sources.shortName: 11 Best things to do in Kanazawa, Japan: a curated travel guide

sources.snippet: Other highlights include guided tours of the magnificent Kanazawa Castle and adjoining Kenrokuen Garden, as well as the Myoriji Temple.
sources.shortName: Best places to stay in Kanazawa, Japan

places.name: Kanazawa Castle

reviews.text:
We visited on the 04/11/2024.

The garden and its surrounding area was beautiful. The castle itself is majestic, from exterior view. There are interesting exhibitions on the castle's history and how it was made.

Beautiful castle viewing. We went on 7th of April which was when the Sakura cherry blossoms were at its peak. The views and blossoms were picturesque in conjunction with the old castle architecture, the city view, the wildlife and the snowy peaks in Gifu. I recommend a guided tour which is free of charge.
Beautifully rebuilt castle.  Take the free tour, also recommend the paid building access sections.  Get a combo ticket with Kenrokuen Gardens.

places.generalDescription: Kanazawa Castle Park is a reconstructed 16th-century castle that once served as the hereditary residence of the Maeda family before the 'Meiji Restoration.' The park, located in Kanazawa City, Ishikawa Prefecture, features extensive surrounding gardens and is adjacent to Kenliu Garden. Visitors can explore historical structures like Ishikawa Gate and enjoy tours of the area. The park is particularly popular during cherry blossom season when the night cherry blossoms create a stunning display.

sources.snippet: Between Kanazawa Station and Katamachi you'll find this market, reminiscent of Tokyo's old Tsukiji market. A bustling warren of fishmongers, buyers and‚Ä¶
sources.shortName: Must-see attractions Kanazawa, Kanazawa & the Hokuriku Coast

sources.snippet: You‚Äôll get to watch the lion dance and historical re-enactments of Maeda Toshiie riding on horseback for an entertaining glimpse into Kanazawa history from Kanazawa Castle Park and in the street during the parade. In the evening, you‚Äôll want to rent a yukata from one of Kanazawa‚Äôs kimono and yukata rental shops and join over ten thousand people converging in the streets for the Hyakumangoku Dancing Parade, with spectators in summer yukata joining the lively evening of festival dances. During the three days of the Kanazawa Hyakumangoku Festival, Kenrokuen Garden opens to the public free of charge and an illumination event is also being held.
sources.siteName: VISIT KANAZAWA, JAPAN - Official Travel Guide
sources.shortName: Summer attraction in KanazawaÔΩúTrip IdeasÔΩúVISIT KANAZAWA, JAPAN

sources.snippet: Exiting the garden via the Katsurazaka Gate, you will see a bridge leading to Kanazawa Castle Park. Home to the ruling Maeda Clan, the castle is a relatively recent reconstruction yet nevertheless, a beautiful and relaxing area to wander through. The grounds can be entered and enjoyed free of charge but to enter specific structures such as the Gojukken Nagaya Storehouse and Hishi and Tsuzuki Yagura turrets costs JPY320.
sources.shortName: 30 Things to Do Around Kanazawa & Where to Stay

sources.snippet:
Kanazawa Castle
Although nothing remains of the original castle here and the few buildings standing are much more recent reconstructions, this park is well worth a visit to enjoy the greenery and the views in all directions (the park is located on a hilltop). On clear days, you can see as far as Mt. Hakusan (2702m). You can walk through some of the gates and climb up some of the reconstructed walls to enjoy the views.
sources.shortName: Things To Do In Kanazawa

sources.snippet: Adjacent to Kenrokuen, explore the historic Kanazawa Castle Park, offering panoramic views of the cityscape and a glimpse into Kanazawa's feudal past. The castle, originally built in the late 1500s, has been partially reconstructed, showcasing impressive architecture and defense mechanisms from the period. A pedestrian bridge across the street, reminiscent of crossing a historic moat, connects the castle to Kenrokuen.
sources.shortName: 10 Things To Do in Kanazawa: Top Must-See Attractions

sources.snippet: Right around the corner, you will find the breathtaking Kanazawa Castle Park and Kanazawa Castle. This is where the Maeda Clan, a wealthy Samurai family of high-ranking officials, ruled the Kaga Domain from. The Maeda Clan is responsible for the construction of most of Kanazawa‚Äôs spectacular sights ‚Äì including this castle and the neighboring Kenroku-en Garden.
sources.shortName: How to Spend the Best 2 Days in Kanazawa

sources.snippet: While most of the Kanazawa Castle is a reconstruction, the castle grounds are still well-kept and suitable for a nice stroll. Heading here early has its benefits, too. If you get to the Castle Park before the crowds, then you‚Äôll have a lovely natural area to soak up the sun, as well as the white walls of the newly reconstructed turrets.
sources.shortName: 30 of the Best Things to Do in Kanazawa | Japan Travel by NAVITIME

sources.snippet: Kanazawa Castle stands in substantial park grounds in the center of Kanazawa City, and is just across the road from Kanazawa‚Äôs other big attraction, Kenrokuen Garden. The castle has played a central role in Kanazawa‚Äôs history and though once neglected, it has been extensively rebuilt and renovated in recent years.
sources.shortName: Sightseeing in Kanazawa ‚Äì Kanazawa Station

places.name: Kanazawa Castle Park

reviews.text:
There are not many interior areas set up for tourists, but the castle grounds are quite large and impressive. The park is beautiful if it's in season. During the day, it's a great but not amazing place.

However, at night it becomes truly spectacular. The lighting gives the whole area a unique atmosphere.

An absolutely stunning castle complex, beautifully restored after the original structure was tragically destroyed by fire. The reconstruction has been done with incredible attention to historical detail, allowing visitors to experience the grandeur of traditional Japanese architecture in a very authentic way.

The grounds are expansive and well-maintained, offering plenty of space to explore and take in the views. Adjacent to the castle is a traditional Japanese garden, which is considered one of the most beautiful in the country. With its seasonal flowers, serene ponds, and meticulously landscaped paths, it's a peaceful retreat and a highlight in its own right.

A must-visit for history lovers, architecture enthusiasts, and anyone looking to experience a deeper side of Japan's cultural heritage.

Pretty good. The castle internally itself isn't something you want to be hyped about. But the outer grounds and some of the surrounding gardens was beautiful. I still found the internals of the castle to be better than Osaka castle, purely because it was less cramped with people. The grounds and the surrounding gardens is something to be in aw of.

sources.snippet: Among our favorite dining experiences was Okina Sushi (Okina Sushi - 2 Chome-1-5 Hikosomachi, Kanazawa, Ishikawa 920-0901, Japan) where the owners, an adorable older couple, gave us hospitality and authentic cuisine that left a lasting impression. They were so warm and welcoming, but I didn‚Äôt feel the same welcome or warmth from places like in Kyoto. The owners of Okina spoke very little English but made a huge effort, and we dined mostly with other locals.
sources.shortName: Reddit - Dive into anything

reviews.text: Came here because of the multiple good reviews and it did not disappoint. Ordering was really easy and straight forward. The staff were so friendly. We had the upper sushi set that comes with a miso soup and the plum wine. Would come back if I could! It is a small place and they only accept cash.

We were welcomed in by he nicest elderly couple. It was the best sushi we had in Japan, and because of this and the license to handle Fugu ( blowfish) we also tried the famous fish!  Everything was amazing , we chat with the owners and asked about the process of cooking fugu and they were delighted to talk to us! We strongly recommend this restaurant!

This is our best meal on this trip both in terms of food quality and hospitality. We don't speak Japanese but the owners were very warm, welcoming and willing to speak to us in both English and Japanese. We enjoyed our freshly prepared sushi and sashimi + plum wine and beer. Tea and small meat plate was on the house.

places.generalDescription: The Ishikawa Prefectural Museum of Art is an elegant and modern facility showcasing a collection of regional Japanese artwork and artifacts. The museum features a traditional collection, displaying ancient Japanese paintings, evocative sculptures, local folk crafts, and treasures of the Maeda family. It also hosts traveling exhibits and contains masterpieces of Kutani and other Kaga arts. The building itself is quite elegant with tall structures and marble decorations.

sources.snippet: This museum occupies three large red brick buildings in Honda-no-Mori Park, not far from Kenrokuen Garden. The buildings themselves are former armories dating back to the Meiji and Taisho Period from the latter half of the 19 th and early 20 th centuries. The central building holds the ticket office and shop as well as areas where you can try on various historical costumes or get a traditional classroom experience.
sources.shortName: Kanazawa‚Äôs Top 4 Rainy Day Activities ‚Äì Kanazawa Tours

sources.snippet: The Ishikawa Prefectural Museum of Art showcases the area‚Äôs tradition of fine art, which thrived under the wealthy Kaga Domain2 during the Edo Period (1603‚Äì1867). Much of the collection used to belong to the Maeda Clan3. The seven gallery spaces feature local ceramics, lacquer ware, Buddhist paintings, Kaga-yuzen silk kimonos, samurai swords, including a National Treasure and four Important Cultural Properties.
sources.shortName: Things To Do | Kanazawa Port

sources.snippet:
Ishikawa Prefectural Museum for Traditional Products and Crafts ¬© sodaigomi
Often overlooked by visitors who rush to the 21st Century Museum of Contemporary Art, this fine museum of Japanese art is well worth a visit. The small but excellent collection covers the main fields of Japanese art. And, downstairs, there‚Äôs a brilliant caf√© where you can refuel with some delicious coffee, tea and pastries.
sources.shortName: Things To Do In Kanazawa

sources.snippet: Ishikawa Prefectural Museum of Art (also called IPMA) was founded in 1959 and holds a fine art and crafts collection which includes many local cultural assets as well as many works by local artists and craftsmen. The collection spans five centuries and includes antiques from the Maeda family collection as well as modern works of art from the 20th century.
sources.shortName: Sightseeing in Kanazawa ‚Äì Kanazawa Station

sources.snippet: Outside of the garden's Katsurazaka gate, the pedestrian road is lined with small restaurants and cafes serving casual lunch dishes, tea, and ice cream covered in gold leaf. Kanazawa accounts for 99% percent of all domestic gold leaf production. Several cafes, shops, and even museums offer gold leaf in various forms.
sources.shortName: Kenrokuen Garden | Travel Japan

places.name: Ishikawa Prefectural Museum of Art

reviews.text: A nice museum. Very cheap admission, the building was very nice and the works are organized into 6 large rooms. Good for art and history lovers and being able to eat at Le Musee de H afterward is a huge plus

A good professional museum but it looks like there was a special exhibition installation happening so i only saw permanent collections. I think they have far too many photo bans on various works. That needs to change. Cafe is spectacular but i just had a coffee as the cakes looked far to rich for my taste.

Large museum for the area that has everything from paintings and sculptures to pottery and tapestries. Also many styles of art from classic to modern on display. Great place and my favorite of the museums in Kanazawa.

places.generalDescription: Naga-machi District, located on the west side of the city and near Korinbo District, is a charming village known for its cobblestone streets and well-preserved samurai homes. Visitors can explore a collection of restored samurai houses along two picturesque canals, with the option to enter and look around. Walking north along the canal behind Kohrinbo 109 Building and then south along the next canal leads to various restaurants and cafes.

sources.snippet: Like the yukitsuri of Kenrokuen Garden, the Nagamachi Samurai District also undergoes a transformation in winter designed to protect its precious assets. Straw mats are hung over the earthen walls of the residences along the streets, protecting them from becoming soaked with water which would damage the walls. It's an important and meaningful tradition that has been carried out through the centuries and is a quintessential winter scene in Kanazawa.
sources.siteName: VISIT KANAZAWA, JAPAN - Official Travel Guide
sources.shortName: Winter Attractions in Kanazawa | VISIT KANAZAWA

sources.snippet: Stroll through the Nagamachi Samurai District to admire streets lined with earthen-walled houses and to see the Nomura Samurai House. Evening ambles through one of the three teahouse ‚Äî ‚Äòchaya‚Äô ‚Äî districts, where geishas still play traditional instruments, also come highly recommended. Other highlights include guided tours of the magnificent Kanazawa Castle and adjoining Kenrokuen Garden, as well as the Myoriji Temple.
sources.shortName: Best places to stay in Kanazawa, Japan

sources.snippet: The Nagamachi Samurai District is home to centuries-old estates that preserve traditional samurai residences. Set behind large wooden gates is the Nomura-ke Samurai House, the former home of a prominent samurai family. This residence has been restored to its former glory and features hand-painted sliding doors and a compact garden that is painstakingly curated, not to mention a display of samurai swords.
sources.shortName: 30 of the Best Things to Do in Kanazawa | Japan Travel by NAVITIME

sources.snippet: For those who will be sightseeing in Kanazawa in Kimono, make sure Nagamachi Samurai District is on your itinerary. You will blend in perfectly into the samurais‚Äô houses in the background. If you are into the local craftwork, such as the Kutani Ware (‰πùË∞∑ÁÑº), you will also find a couple of nice little shops in one of these traditional houses that might make you lose track of your time (¬¥‚ñΩÔΩÄ*).
sources.siteName: Vegetarian's Japan Guide | Ultimate Japan Guide, Vegetarian-Friendly, Hidden Gems in Japan
sources.shortName: Your Ultimate Kanazawa City Travel Guide 2024

sources.snippet: The historic Nagamachi District was where the middle to high-ranking samurai once lived. It retains many features from the Edo Period (1603-1867) Ôºç narrow cobblestone streets, drainage and water supply systems, and samurai houses. Restored to their former glory, many of these samurai homes are tucked away behind thick earthen walls with distinctive clay or wooden tiles.
sources.shortName: Things To Do | Kanazawa Port

sources.snippet: Now that you enjoyed a delicious lunch, venture out and explore the beautiful Nagamachi District. You will see that this district features small houses and restaurants, traditional ‚Äúearth walls‚Äù, and there‚Äôs a small ‚Äúriver‚Äù that flows throughout the district. You will also find wonderful artisan shops that I highly recommend checking out and supporting!
sources.shortName: How to Spend the Best 2 Days in Kanazawa

sources.snippet: Nagamachi is a beautifully preserved historic area of Kanazawa that was once the residential district for the city‚Äôs samurai. It is a lovely area of canals and stone-flagged winding lanes that run between tile-topped earthern walls. Some of the former samurai houses and their gardens are also open for public viewing.
sources.shortName: Sightseeing in Kanazawa ‚Äì Kanazawa Station

sources.snippet: Visit Kanazawa Castle, an impressive 16th-century fortress, and immerse yourselves in the city's rich samurai heritage with a trip to the Nagamachi District, where you can even try on traditional samurai armor.
sources.shortName: Tripper - Guide - A romantic day trip to Kanazawa, Japan

sources.snippet: The tour also includes visits to the well-preserved Nagamachi Samurai District and the stunning Kanazawa Castle, allowing visitors to explore the rich history and traditions of Kanazawa.
sources.shortName: Romantic Tour In Kanazawa
Things To Do | Ishikawa Travel
30 Things to Do Around Kanazawa & Where to Stay

places.name: Nagamachi Samurai District

reviews.text: We visited the district at night. It was just one or two streets. The buildings were partly modernized but the old town atmosphere was still wonderful. It gave us a glimpse of the past when samurais lived there.

It's really the walls of the bygone era. Most of the houses, even though large, were built after the area revitalised.  Large parcels of land. The Samauri House is worth a visit to give you perspective of what the homes were like. This is only a partial part of the home that remains. The carvings, silk screen doors, courtyard, and gardens give a glimpse as to the decor. The structure is deceiving and larger than appears. The gardens tranquil with 3 large koi drifting casually in pond. Other houses have beautiful entries. It's clearly now an upmarket area in which to live. The alleyways offer the idea with narrow lanes walled on either side. It's not a large area but easy to pass 2-3 hours. Shopping runs parallel to area. Old canal passes through area where water was drawn from.

A peaceful area to stroll and admire the preserved architecture from the samurai era. The streets are lined with earthen walls and traditional structures that give a glimpse into the past.

Overall it was a relaxing walk, but the district is not very big, so it does not take long to cover. Still worth a quick stop if you are nearby, especially if you plan to visit Nomura Samurai House which is within the area.

places.generalDescription: Gyokusen-an is a well-known former geisha house dating back to 1820, featuring an impressive collection of elaborate combs. Visitors can enjoy matcha green tea and unbaked sweets while admiring the beautiful garden. The space offers a high-quality experience with polite explanations about namagashi and unique namagashi only available at this location.

sources.snippet: An Important Cultural Asset, this well-known, traditional-style former geisha house dates from 1820 and has an impressive collection of elaborate combs,‚Ä¶
sources.shortName: Must-see attractions Kanazawa, Kanazawa & the Hokuriku Coast

sources.snippet: Also in the park is Gyokusenan, the tea room overlooking Gyokuseninmaru Garden, another location to enjoy a hot matcha tea and confectionery while getting out of the cold.
sources.siteName: VISIT KANAZAWA, JAPAN - Official Travel Guide
sources.shortName: Winter Attractions in Kanazawa | VISIT KANAZAWA

places.name: Gyokusen-an

reviews.text: Incredibly beautiful place, perfect for a stop. Has very beautiful view on the garden and air conditioning (a relief in summer). We had cold matcha and a traditional sweet. The staff was very kind. It was very calm and not crowded at all. Much better than we expected. I wish we had booked the tea ceremony as well ! Must visit!

The most amazing find. If this is ur first stop. Please give urself a few hours at this castle because there are tons of this tea stop along the whole park. I suggest to stop at each and enjoy tea and a view. This was our first. Warning it is a quiet place for reflection and meditation. Great photo opportunity as well.
Great view, excellent wagashi, beautiful wares and good service. I wish the tea had a stronger taste, and there were clumps at the bottom of my bowl.

places.generalDescription: Kanazawa Chaya Ryokan offers a blend of traditional charm and modern luxury, featuring stylish rooms, spacious public baths, and an exquisite Japanese restaurant. The upscale design includes lattice windows, paper screens, and tatami floors in each room. Guests can relax in yukata-style nightwear provided by the ryokan. This traditional inn provides a unique experience with tatami straw floors and futon mattresses for sleeping.

sources.snippet: Chaya Ryokan, in downtown Kanazawa, is an upscale city choice. Unwind in the sauna, kick back in classic guest rooms, or savour splendid kaiseki dishes in the chic restaurant. For romantics or well-heeled history buffs.
sources.shortName: Best places to stay in Kanazawa, Japan

places.name: Kanazawa Chaya Ryokan

reviews.text:
So this is the most 'value' I think I have in my Japanese trips (which are mainly with 4/5 stars hotels if available). Very centrally located next to the train station that you can walk even when it's raining. The food is the best and they offered two locations for two nights. They have a public bath that's not onsen but still help us to relax. Room on the small side I think. Service is very accomodative which is what I love.

Top rating!

Definitely coming back here. This is a great higher end Ryokan experience. Very comfortable accommodation, wonderful hospitality and service from all the staff and the kaiseki dinners and breakfasts were exceptional.

We have stayed at Chaya Ryokan for two nights and I have to say that was incredible.
If you want to live a real traditional ryokan experience this is the place.
Thanks to all the staff that made us feel like better than at home.
The food was excellent and traditional !
